Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Hojooba' bee la' hooniil, Undergraduate Studies into the Social Psychophysiology of Compassion

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project represents an enhancement of a previously funded (2010-12) REU Site program with the thematic focus on Undergraduate Studies into the Social Psychophysiology of Compassion (SPC) in the Department of Psychology at the Northern Arizona University. It builds upon a successful legacy of this university's prior REU Site by providing research experiences for 8 Native American, Hispanic, African American, Native Alaskan, and Native Hawaiian/Pacific Islander students, including first generation college/university students who are disabled, female, White, and Veterans. Each student conducts research focused on Compassion, under guidance of active Psychology Department researchers. The PI-team continues the previously successful program with significant improvements and an increased recruitment of primarily Native American community college students.

Intellectual Merit:
This research internship addresses 8 important intellectual components: (1) Direct, closely supervised, hands-on original research experiences in individual faculty laboratories provided by an experienced, productive, and stimulating faculty research mentor, (2) Faculty seminars on various aspects of scientific research, (3) Professional, educational, cultural, and career development seminars, (4) Weekly noon science symposia, (5) A variety of unique educational, cultural, environmental, and social activities, (6) Student presentations at a local professional REU conference, (7) Presentation of research outcomes at national professional conferences, and (8) Co-participation of Psychology REU students with REU students from other programs in seminars, lectures, and local research presentations. Students thus participate collegially in original and pioneering compassion research.

Broader Impacts:
This program has far-reaching implications for both the expansion of scientific thinking and inquiry and the advancement of society. (1) Direct recruitment of underrepresented minority students via live campus visits and presentations, innovative college liaisons toward increased engagement of underserved minorities in research, and onsite research and educational collaborations of minority students and faculty greatly broadens participation of under-represented minorities in social science research. Tangible research outcomes, student presentations at professional meetings, research mentoring, and collegial group sharing of the research process developed over a 10-week summer session and continuing into the AY give each student a sense of ownership in a scientific project and process, and a personalization of the experience to facilitate continued careers in science. (2) Intensive collaboration with dedicated career academic researchers and teaching during weekly seminars by undergraduate students from diverse cultural backgrounds is very likely to instill a lasting excitement for science in general and for the SPC specialty areas in particular, thus advancing creative discovery while simultaneously promoting cross-fertilization of scientific exploration, knowledge acquisition, skills training, and a commitment to the art of teaching and research. (3) Utilization of existing educational training facilities for summer internships enhances the university?s research and educational infrastructure. (4) Participation of interns and mentors in interdisciplinary seminars, workshops, research, education, and national conferences broadens dissemination and enhances interdisciplinary scientific understanding. (5) The proposed innovative and comprehensive analysis of this REU program allows for a yearly evaluation and fine-tuning to better achieve objectives and to improve the future identification, training, and development of behavioral research scientists in this country. Most importantly, and perhaps most uniquely for our program, (6) the research projects and thematic focus on compassion offer important answers to probing societal questions and ultimate benefits to society, and, we hope, the development of a generation of young researchers whose careers are dedicated to the understanding and creation of the expression of compassion, the easing of suffering of others, and the promotion of a more compassionate world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Since the broad goal of REU programs is to produce a cadre of undergraduate students heretofore under-represented in the sciences who desire to pursue careers in the social sciences and ultimately to obtain employment within the professoriate teaching and conducting research, the impact of our REU is measured by our ability to recruit the desired undergraduate cohort and to excite them with the adventure of conducting their own research project in the general thematic area of Compassion and to increase the likelihood that these students will move onward in their academic program toward careers in the social and behavioral sciences professoriate.  Over the past 3 years, we therefore actively extended our directed recruitment activities at regional Southwestern community colleges targeting Native American students. This effort culminated in our receiving 183 applicants to our program by the 3rd year, and we are pleased that our targeted applicant pool exceeded the 2011 percentage distribution of minority students enrolled in degree-seeking institutions posted by the DOE National Center for Education Statistics.  Furthermore, by our 3rd year, our pool of accepted interns were all underrepresented minorities, with our targeted Native American applicant pool 5 times larger than the national average, and with our Native American acceptance pool 12.5 times greater than the national average! 

Programmatically, our REU was very well received by our interns. On a Likert rating scale from 1-5, with 5 the highest most positive rating, by the 3rd year, our Intern ratings ranged from a low of 2.63 to a high of 4.88, the latter a perfect to near-perfect rating by all interns. Over 67% of the ratings were 4.0 and above.  Furthermore, all of our interns planned on continuing their education on to graduate school and most into careers in science.  We are most pleased to report that, to date, 11 of our previous REU Interns were accepted into very prestigious doctoral training programs or have moved into related career fields.

With regard to productivity, our REU interns have been very productive indeed. Over the prior 3 summers of REU research, each of our 25 interns produced a tangible research outcome from their internship, prepared and presented a poster and a PowerPoint oral presentation at our Annual REU Research Conference at the Hign Country Conference Center in Flagstaff, and went on to present their research at regional and/or national conferences. For example, for just the 3rd year, a total of 8 separate research projects were conducted, with 8 poster sessions, 16 oral presentations, and 1 manuscript submitted and under review for publication. And, each Spring following a Summer internship, we submit for a Compassion Symposium to be presented at the prestigious Annual Convention of the American Psychological Association (APA), the largest psychology convention in the world and a point of congregation of most of the prominent professionals in this field. For the 2017 125th Annual Convention of the APA, we submitted two symposia, one, “Recent Discoveries in the Neuroscience of Empathy, Compassion, and Self-Compassion” and the other, “The Social Psychology of Empathy, Compassion, and Self-Compassion”. We are very pleased to report that both symposia were accepted and were presented by all 8  interns, with their mentors in attendance and with two mentors as Symposium Discussants, at the APA Convention on August 3-6, 2017 in Washington, DC. We are particularly pleased that the Social Psychology symposium was presented to a standing-room only crowd and both were very well received with lively discussions following each presentation. These national symposia represent a peak experience for our interns, putting our REU program “on the map” among psychology researchers and exposing our interns to vital connections for future graduate training.

And finally, at the APA Annual Convention in Toronto, Canada in August 2015, we presented our “Exploring the Neuroscience of Empathy, Compassion, and Self-Compassion” REU Symposium to a standing-room only crowd in a conference room holding over 200 attendees. Two book publishers also attended that convention and after our symposium, both approached Dr. Woodruff, my fellow Mentor and Discussant for the Symposium, and myself and offered us a book deal over the content of the symposium and our REU research. In late 2015, we signed a book contract for an edited academic research text called The Neuroscience of Empathy, Compassion, and Self-Compassion published in Spring 2018 by Elsevier/Academic Press, a very prestigious publishing house indeed. Dr. Woodruff and I edited and/or wrote each of 11 chapters authored by a panel of researchers from across the world, some of whom include our former REU Interns and Mentors. We are very excited about this book publication,a direct outcome of the NSF-funded REU experiences at NAU, and feel that it will represents a pioneering and comprehensive academic research publication in the fields of empathy, compassion, and self-compassion.
